maml:description.maml:para: Add\Insert one or more BSON documents into a litedb database.
Add\Insert one or more BSON documents into a litedb database.

maml:Description.maml:para: The collection or table name.
Specify an array of BSON documents to insert. Useful in bulk insert scenarios.
The number of documents to insert in one single batch
use with bsonarray for bulk inserting documents.
The litedb connection object.
The collection or table name.
The BSON document to add to the litedb database.
The litedb connection object.
The collection or table name.
specify the id of the bson document to be added.
The BSON document to add to the litedb database.
The litedb connection object.
The number of documents to insert in one single batch
Specify an array of BSON documents to insert. Useful in bulk insert scenarios.
use with bsonarray for bulk inserting documents.
The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.
The BSON document to add to the litedb database.
specify the id of the bson document to be added.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $mymovie = [PSCustomObject]@{ Title = 'Turner & Hooch' _id = 3 Budget = [int64]13000001 Gross = [int64]71079915 MPAA = 'PG' Rating = 7.2 RatingCount = 91415 ReleaseDate = [Datetime]'7/28/1989' RunTime = 101 }
$mymovie | ConvertTo-LiteDbBSON | Add-LiteDBDocument -Collection movies

dev:remarks.maml:para: add a powershell customobject containing movie data into a collection named 'movies'. Note: this assumes that the litedb database already contains a collection named 'movies'. Before we can add a document to the litedb the powershell object needs to be converted into a format(BSONDocument) that Litedb can understand.

maml:description.maml:para: Close\Dispose an open litedb connection.
Close\Dispose an open litedb connection.

maml:Description.maml:para: The litedbconnection object.
The litedbconnection object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will close the default litedb connection stored in the hidden variable - $LiteDBPSConnection
This will close the litedb connection stored in the variable - $myconnection

maml:description.maml:para: Convert psobjects into LiteDB compatible BSON documents key-value pair.
Convert psobjects into LiteDB compatible BSON documents key-value pair.

maml:Description.maml:para: psobject to be converted to bson document.
the depth of serialization of psobjetcs.
Output as a single document or as an array(useful when you want to do add\insert documents in batches)
Output as a single document or as an array(useful when you want to do add\insert documents in batches)
the depth of serialization of psobjetcs.
psobject to be converted to bson document.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> PS C:\> $mymovie = [PSCustomObject]@{ Title = 'Turner & Hooch' _id = 3 Budget = [int64]13000001 Gross = [int64]71079915 MPAA = 'PG' Rating = 7.2 RatingCount = 91415 ReleaseDate = [Datetime]'7/28/1989' RunTime = 101 }
$mymovie | ConvertTo-LiteDbBSON

dev:remarks.maml:para: converts the psobject stored in the variable $mymovie into a bsondocument(key,value)pair.

List objects in either of 2 formats: PSObject or BSON document.

The number of documents to be listed.
Ignores the specified number of objects and then gets the remaining objects. Enter the number of objects to skip.
The collection or table name.
List objects in either of 2 formats: PSObject or BSON document.
The litedb connection object.

Where filter criteria by BSOn expression.

Find documents by a SQL statement.
List objects in either of 2 formats: PSObject or BSON document.

Ignores the specified number of objects and then gets the remaining objects. Enter the number of objects to skip.
List objects in either of 2 formats: PSObject or BSON document.

Where filter criteria by BSOn expression.

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all documents inside the movies collection.
List the first 5 documents inside the movies collection.
List document with ID 6 inside the movies collection.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Find-LiteDBDocument movies -Sql "Select $ from movies limit 5"

dev:remarks.maml:para: List the first 5 documents inside the movies collection using a SQL statement.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Find-LiteDBDocument movies -Sql "Select _id,Title,MPAA from movies where MPAA='PG-13'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all documents inside the movies collection whose MPAA property value matches 'PG-13'. Note: We only retrieve a select few properties(_id,Title,MPAA) of the collection.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 6 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Find-LiteDBDocument movies -Sql "Select concat(string(_id),MPAA) as concat,_id,MPAA from movies where MPAA='PG-13'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Concatenate 2 fields _id & MPAA and show that as a new calculated field 'concat' Note: this does not actually add the field concat to the collection.
List 3 properties of all documents that match the where criteria.
Show the field Title as MovieName. Note: this does not actually rename the field Title to moviename.

maml:description.maml:para: List all collections in a litedb database.
List all collections in a litedb database.

maml:Description.maml:para: The litedb connection object.
The litedb connection object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-LiteDBCollectionName
Connection collection AutoId Docs ---------- ---------- ------ ---- LiteDB.LiteDatabase one ObjectId 3 LiteDB.LiteDatabase test ObjectId 0 LiteDB.LiteDatabase movies ObjectId 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: shows 3 collections along with the document count in each collection.

maml:description.maml:para: List all indices for a litedb database.
List all indices for a litedb database.

maml:Description.maml:para: The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.
The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-LiteDBIndex -Collection 'one'
collection : one Connection : LiteDB.LiteDatabase name : _id expression : $._id unique : True maxLevel : 7

dev:remarks.maml:para: _id field which is mandatory is indexed by default.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new collection\table in a litedb database.
Create a new collection\table in a litedb database.

maml:Description.maml:para: The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.
The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new collection named 'movies'.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new litedb database on the file system.
Creates a new litedb database on the file system.

maml:Description.maml:para: Path to LiteDB database
Credential to secure the database
Credential to secure the database
Path to LiteDB database

dev:remarks.maml:para: creates a new litedb database at c:\temp\movie.db
creates a new litedb database at c:\temp\movie.db with password protection. In order to open the database you would have to provide the password used when the db was created.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new LiteDb index.

Create a new LiteDb index. Even if multiple indexed expressions are used on a query, only one of the indexes is used, with the remaining expressions being filtered using a full scan. Index keys must have at most 1023 bytes Up to 255 indexes per collections, including the _id primary key, but limited to 8096 bytes for index definition. Each index uses: 41 bytes + LEN(name) + LEN(expression)

maml:Description.maml:para: The collection or table name.
The field\property name in the collection that is to be indexed.
The litedb connection object.
The expression based index that is to be created. see http://www.litedb.org/docs/indexes/ & http://www.litedb.org/docs/expressions/
Speicy if the indexed field should allow duplicates.
The collection or table name.
The litedb connection object.
The expression based index that is to be created. see http://www.litedb.org/docs/indexes/ & http://www.litedb.org/docs/expressions/
The field\property name in the collection that is to be indexed.
Speicy if the indexed field should allow duplicates.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates an index on the 'genre' field with the values in lowercase.
Creates an index on the 'Total' field which is a calculated field. Items is a field that contains an array of bson documents with one of the properties in the embedded documents being price.

maml:description.maml:para: Open a connection to a litedb database on the filesystem or in-memory.
Open a connection to a litedb database on the filesystem or in-memory.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass your own connectionstring to LiteDB
Not implemented.
Open datafile in read-only mode
Path to LiteDB database
Credential to secure the database
Not implemented.
Create a LiteDB databse with a specific starting size. By default the starting size is 8 KB.
LiteDB offers 2 types of connections: Direct and Shared. This affect how engine will open data file.

Direct: Engine will open the datafile in exclusive mode and will keep it open until Dispose(). The datafile cannot be opened by another process. This is the recommended mode because it’s faster and cachable. Shared: Engine will be close the datafile after each operation. Locks are made using Mutex. This is more expensive but you can open same file from multiple processes.
Open datafile in read-only mode
Check if datafile is of an older version and upgrade it before opening
A collation is a special pragma (for more info, see Pragmas) that allows users to specify a culture and string compare options for a datafile.
Collation is a read-only pragma and can only be changed with a rebuild.
A collation is specified with the format CultureName/CompareOption1[,CompareOptionN]. For more info about compare options, check the .NET documentation.
Datafiles are always created with CultureInfo.CurrentCulture as their culture and with IgnoreCase as the compare option. The collation can be change by rebuilding the datafile.
Examples: rebuild {"collation": "en-US/None"}; rebuilds the datafile with the en-US culture and regular string comparison
rebuild {"collation": "en-GB/IgnoreCase"}; rebuilds the datafile with the en-GB culture and case-insensitive string comparison

rebuild {"collation": "pt-BR/IgnoreCase,IgnoreSymbols"}; rebuilds the datafile with the pt-BR culture and case-insensitive string comparison that also ignores symbols (white spaces, punctuation, math symbols etc.)
Pass your own connectionstring to LiteDB
Credential to secure the database
Path to LiteDB database
Not implemented.
Create a LiteDB databse with a specific starting size. By default the starting size is 8 KB.
LiteDB offers 2 types of connections: Direct and Shared. This affect how engine will open data file.

Direct: Engine will open the datafile in exclusive mode and will keep it open until Dispose(). The datafile cannot be opened by another process. This is the recommended mode because it’s faster and cachable. Shared: Engine will be close the datafile after each operation. Locks are made using Mutex. This is more expensive but you can open same file from multiple processes.
Open datafile in read-only mode
Check if datafile is of an older version and upgrade it before opening
A collation is a special pragma (for more info, see Pragmas) that allows users to specify a culture and string compare options for a datafile.
Collation is a read-only pragma and can only be changed with a rebuild.
A collation is specified with the format CultureName/CompareOption1[,CompareOptionN]. For more info about compare options, check the .NET documentation.
Datafiles are always created with CultureInfo.CurrentCulture as their culture and with IgnoreCase as the compare option. The collation can be change by rebuilding the datafile.
Examples: rebuild {"collation": "en-US/None"}; rebuilds the datafile with the en-US culture and regular string comparison
rebuild {"collation": "en-GB/IgnoreCase"}; rebuilds the datafile with the en-GB culture and case-insensitive string comparison

rebuild {"collation": "pt-BR/IgnoreCase,IgnoreSymbols"}; rebuilds the datafile with the pt-BR culture and case-insensitive string comparison that also ignores symbols (white spaces, punctuation, math symbols etc.)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Open-LiteDBConnection
Database : ConnectionInfo : Mapper : LiteDB.BsonMapper FileStorage : LiteDB.LiteStorage`1[System.String] UserVersion : 0 Timeout : 00:01:00 UtcDate : False LimitSize : 9223372036854775807 CheckpointSize : 1000 Collation : en-US/IgnoreCase

dev:remarks.maml:para: The database property is empty suggesting that the we are working with an in-memory database.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Open-LiteDBConnection -Database c:\temp\movie.db
Database : C:\temp\movie.db ConnectionInfo : LiteDB.ConnectionString Mapper : LiteDB.BsonMapper FileStorage : LiteDB.LiteStorage`1[System.String] UserVersion : 0 Timeout : 00:01:00 UtcDate : False LimitSize : 9223372036854775807 CheckpointSize : 1000 Collation : en-US/IgnoreCase

dev:remarks.maml:para: Opens a connection to the litedb located at c:\temp\movie.db

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Open-LiteDBConnection -Database c:\temp\movie.db -Credential (Get-Credential)
Database : C:\temp\movie.db ConnectionInfo : LiteDB.ConnectionString Mapper : LiteDB.BsonMapper FileStorage : LiteDB.LiteStorage`1[System.String] UserVersion : 0 Timeout : 00:01:00 UtcDate : False LimitSize : 9223372036854775807 CheckpointSize : 1000 Collation : en-US/IgnoreCase

dev:remarks.maml:para: If you created the database with password protection then the same password will need to be passed every time you want to open the litedb database.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Caution: Removes the collection named 'movies' along with all data stored inside the collection.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove a document by ID
Remove a document(s) by BSON expression. All documents whose MPAA field matches the value 'PG-13' will be removed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-LiteDBDocument 'movies' -Sql "delete movies where ReleaseDate > datetime('12/10/1989')"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove a document(s) by SQL statement. Documents greater than a certain datetime are removed with this sql query.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $mymovie = [PSCustomObject]@{ Title = 'Turner and Hooch' _id = 3 Budget = [int64]13000001 Gross = [int64]71079915 MPAA = 'PG' Rating = 7.2 RatingCount = 91415 ReleaseDate = [Datetime]'7/28/1989' RunTime = 101 }
$mymovie | ConvertTo-LiteDbBSON | Update-LiteDBDocument -Collection movies

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates document with id 3(by ID)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-LiteDBDocument movies -Set "{Title:'Turner and Hooch'}" -Where "_id = 3"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates document with id 3(by BSON expression). The title property value is changed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-LiteDBDocument 'movies' -sql "UPDATE movies SET Title='Turner & Hooch',RunTime = 101 where _id = 3"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Update multiple fields of a document with ID 3(by SQL)
